name: Letter from Clusius, Carolus to Lipsius, Justus, 1593-06-27

Diplomatic.text: S[alutem] P[lurimam], V[ir] Clarissime. Recte factum, quod ad meas, postremis nundinis datas, responderis, ut Ill[ust]ri viro Pinello, qui me de negotio ad te scripto urgere non cessat, habeam quod respondeam. Nam postremis suis, quibus ad eas respondebat, quas 24. Aprilis ad ipsum dabam (scripseram autem me ante octiduum litteras denuo ad te dedisse) in haec verba scribit. Si stara attendendo con desid[erio] la risposta del S[igno]r Lipsio, gia che questo ill[ustrissi]mo Sig[no]r Giovanni Michele Procuratore di S[an] Marco, et insieme riformatore dello studio in Padoua, la sta attendendo con quella devotione, che la S[ignoria] V[ostra] puo facilmente imaginarsi dalle tante repliche, che le ne ho fatte a sua instanza. Ex his facile colligere potes, quam gratus foret illi tuus adventus. Nec dubito quin, si in animum induxeris profectionem istam suscipiendi, valetudo tua sit firmior futura. Nam istic habebis praestantissimos totius Europae medicos, qui (si qui alii) maxime utilia ad valetudinem tuam praescribere poterunt; habes istic vicinas Aponenses Aquas, quas audio vehementer commendari et adeo celebres, ut plurimi non modo ex universa Italia, sed etiam ex regionibus exteris valetudinis recuperandae causa eo confluant. Cupio tibi bene esse, mi Lipsi, ex animo dico, atque utinam tanti apud te momenti mea epistola esse possit, ut propositam conditionem acceptare velis. Significabo Ill[ust]ri Pinello tuam voluntatem, quam non dubito illi gratam fore, sed longe gratiorem, si quid certi de tuo adventu decernere posses. Tuus hortus mihi curae erit. Velim scribas per quem tuas has postremas ad Arnoldum Mylium curaris; Colonia enim ille ad me XX Iunii, sed resignatas; et ipse in epistola culpam fatetur: se videlicet resignasse, non perspecta inscriptione et primum animadvertisse ipsi non fuisse inscriptam, cum eas legere incepisset. Studio potius factum suspicor, quam nimis supina negligentia, nam cum ille totus a novo monachorum genere pendeat, et illi sint vaferrimi cupiantque omnium consilia nosse, facile in suspicionem venio, ab illis mandata accepisse ut ista faciat. Monebo Moretum, ut in posterum quas ad me, dum hic vivam, dabis, suis mihi inscriptis includat. Nunc ad me venio. Singulari sum fato, mi Lipsi, ut in cruribus infortunium accipiam: ante sexennium pes sinister luxatus; ipso die paschatis, vetere calculo, horadecima ante meridiem, ad conventum mercatorum iturus, descendens gradus et infimum iam me attigisse putans, dextrum pedem promoveo, tanquam in plano ambulaturus (obscuriores autem erant gradus) pes subsidens, nec inveniens in quo sisteret, inclinavit totum illud latus et tabulatum pertingens contortus est fecitque ut in latus dextrum caderem adeo graviter, ut coxendicis dextri luxationem metuerem et adhuc metuo aliquam esse, licet et medicus et duo chirurgi aliter sentiant. Is casus valde me afflixit, nam praeter magnos cruciatus quos pertuli, me totis decem septimanis cubiculo inclusum detinet, nec possum adhuc pede dextro uti. Fuit mihi vero is casus tanto gravior, quod meum hortum interea temporis conspicere non potuerim, qui haud dubie per continuas fere praecedentes pluvias multum detrimenti acceperit; nam bulbaceae et tuberosae, quae meae delitiae, nimia humiditate plurimum laeduntur et plerumque etiam pereunt. Huc accedit quod toto isto tempore nihil scribere, nihil commentari potuerim et breve restat tempus ad Nundinas, quibus praeteritis, mihi ad eos proficiscendum, apud quos, Deo volente, quietam sedem inveniam. Cras thermas Weisbadenses accedere animus est, ut experiar an illae sint futurae salubres. Sed chartae angustia ut longior sim non patitur; itaque bene vale, mi Lipsi. Francofurti ad Moenum V K[alendas] Iulii MDXCIII. D[ominus] Bongarsius plurimam ex animo reddit salutem. T[uus] Car[olus] Clusius. [Address:] C[larissimo] V[iro] Domino Iusto Lipsio Professori in Academia Lovaniensi, Domino et amico observando. Lovanium.

annotations.text: Nundinas: Clusius vainly hoped to have the fifth and sixth part of his Stirpium Historia completed before coming to Leiden.
postremis suis: This letter is not preserved, but the invitation is already mentioned in a former letter from Pinelli to Clusius, dated 13 March 1593.

annotations.text: ante ... luxatus: When Clusius was still living in Vienna, he had slipped off a few steps in the steam baths in Vienna on 29 December 1586 and sprained his left foot, cf. ILE II, 87 03 22 / 04 01, 10-11 (n. 11 is not correct: not this fall of 1586, maar the one expounded upon in this letter would cripple Clusius for the rest of his days).
thermas Weisbadenses: The waters of Schwalbach, NW of Wiesbaden, where he sought to alleviate his pain.
Moretum: Johannes Moretus who, as a printer, had often business contacts with Frankfurt.

annotations.text: Mylium: Arnoldus Mylius (Moers, 16 October 1540 – Cologne, 17 November 1604) lkibrarian and printer in Cologne. He learned his trade in the Antwerp branch of the Cologne librarian Birckmann. For religious reasons he emigrated to Cologne, where he married with Barbara Birckmann and became the manager and the confidant of Birckmann’s heirs. He had contacts with many well-known humanists.

annotations.text: ut ... respondeam: Clusius sent Lipsius’s answer, in which he declined the invitation, to Pinelli on 7 July, as it becomes clear from Pinelli’s reaction, dated 27 July.
paschatis: Easter 1593 fell on 15 April according to the Julian calendar (= 25 April according to the Gregorian calendar).
bulbaceae: Clusius had devoted himself in particular to the tulip family,a plant of which Lipsius was also very fond.
negotio: The Venetians had offered Lipsius a chair at the University of Padua and had urged Clusius to support their invitation.

aliter sentiant: Later Clusius reproached the physicians of Frankfurt for stubornly maintaining that he was not suffering a luxation, whereas a physician in Leiden had instantly made this diagnose, cf. ILE VII, 94 03 02.
Aponenses Aquas: Aponus, now Bagni d’Abano (Abano Termi), therapeutic warm water source near Padua, already known in Antiquity, cf. Plin. H. N. 2, 103, 106, 227; Suet. Tib. 14.
